sen.j: 蘆名（あしな）氏は、平氏系統の三浦氏から興った氏族で、蘆名（現在横須賀市芦名）の地名に由来する。
sen.e: The Ashina clan was descended from the Taira clan through the Miura clan with the name Ashina (蘆名) derived from a placename Ashina (present Ashina (芦名) in Yokosuka City).
The Ashina clan was descended from the Taira clan through the Miura clan with the name Ashina (蘆名) derived from the name of the area known as Ashina (present Ashina (芦名) in Yokosuka City).
The Ashina clan was descended from the Taira clan through the Miura clan with the name Ashina (蘆名) derived from the name of the area known as Ashina (present Ashina (芦名) in Yokosuka City).

sen.j: 「芦名氏」、「葦名氏」と表記される事もある。
sen.e: Some Ashina families in the clan are written as 芦名 and 葦名.
Some Ashina families in the clan were written as 芦名 and 葦名.
Some Ashina families in the clan were written as 芦名 and 葦名.

sen.j: 相模蘆名氏と会津蘆名氏の二つの系統が存在する。
sen.e: The Ashina clan had two lines: the Sagami Ashina and the Aizu Ashina.
The Ashina clan had two lines: the Sagami Ashina and the Aizu Ashina.
The Ashina clan had two lines: the Sagami Ashina and the Aizu Ashina.

sen.j: 通し字は前者は「為」、後者は「盛」。
sen.e: Toshiji (or toriji, character-in-common, one of two Chinese characters adopted by members of the same family) for the Sagami Ashina was Tame (為) and for the Aizu Ashina was Mori (盛).
Toshiji (or toriji, character-in-common, one of two Chinese characters adopted by members of the same family) for the Sagami Ashina was Tame (為) and for the Aizu Ashina was Mori (盛).

The Chinese character "為" (pronounced "tame" in Japanese) was used in all the names of the members of the Ashina clan, while the character "盛" ("mori") was used in all the names of the members of the Aizu Ashina clan.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 相模蘆名氏
sen.e: Sagami Ashina
Sagami Ashina
Sagami Ashina

sen.j: 三浦義継の三男・蘆名為清が蘆名姓を名乗ったことに始まる。
sen.e: Sagami Ashina originated from Tamekiyo ASHINA, the third son of Yoshitsugu MIURA, who first bore the name of Ashina.
Sagami Ashina originated from Tamekiyo ASHINA, the third son of Yoshitsugu MIURA, who first bore the name of Ashina.
Sagami Ashina originated from Tamekiyo ASHINA, the third son of Yoshitsugu MIURA, who first bore the name of Ashina.

sen.j: 孫の石田為久は源義仲を討ち取り、褒章として近江国石田村を与えられ、一族は同地に移住した。
sen.e: Tamehisa ISHIDA, a grandson of Yoshitsugu MIURA, was granted Ishida-mura village in Omi Province in reward for having slain MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka, and moved to the village with his clan.
Tamehisa ISHIDA, a grandson of Yoshitsugu MIURA, was granted Ishida-mura village in Omi Province in reward for having slain MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka, and moved to the village with his clan.
Tamehisa ISHIDA, a grandson of Yoshitsugu MIURA, was granted Ishida-mura village in Omi Province in reward for having slain MINAMOTO no Yoshinaka, and moved to the village with his clan.

sen.j: その後、石田氏と婚姻を重ねて京極氏の被官となり、戦国時代 (日本)には石田三成を輩出（石田三成が、名門蘆名氏の流れを自称した可能性もある）した。
sen.e: Thereafter, his family members entered into matrimony with the members of Ishida family to be hikan (low-level bureaucrat) of the Kyogoku clan, from which Mitsunari ISHIDA was descended in the Warring States period (Japan) (Mitsunari ISHIDA may have announced himself a descendant of the distinguished Ashina clan.)

Thereafter, his family members entered into matrimony with the members of the Ishida family to be hikan (low-level bureaucrat) of the Kyogoku clan, from which Mitsunari ISHIDA was descended in the Warring States period (Japan) (Mitsunari ISHIDA may have announced himself a descendant of the distinguished Ashina clan.)

Thereafter, his family members entered into matrimony with the members of the Ishida family to be hikan (low-level bureaucrat) of the Kyogoku clan, from which Mitsunari ISHIDA was descended in the Warring States period (Japan) (Mitsunari ISHIDA may have announced himself a descendant of the distinguished Ashina clan).

sen.j: また、鎌倉時代中期には蘆名経光が伯耆守護となっている。
sen.e: In the mid Kamakura period, Tsunemitsu ASHINA became Shugo (military governor) of Hoki Province.
In the mid Kamakura period, Tsunemitsu ASHINA became Shugo (military governor) of Hoki Province.
In the mid Kamakura period, Tsunemitsu ASHINA became Shugo (military governor) of Hoki Province.

sen.j: 会津蘆名氏
sen.e: Aizu Ashina
Aizu Ashina
Aizu Ashina

sen.j: 三浦義明の七男・佐原義連を初代とするが、蘆名姓を名乗るのは、義連の孫に当たる光盛の代になってからである（異説あり）。
sen.e: Yoshitsuna SAHARA, the seventh son of Yoshiaki MIURA, was the founder, but the family began to bear the name Ashina from the generation of Yoshiaki's grandson Mitsumori (there are different opinions.).

While Yoshitsuna SAHARA, the seventh son of Yoshiaki MIURA, was the founder, the family only began to bear the name Ashina starting from the Yoshiaki's grandson Mitsumori's (there are different opinions.) generation.

While Yoshitsuna SAHARA, the seventh son of Yoshiaki MIURA, was the founder, the family only began to bear the name Ashina starting from the Yoshiaki's grandson Mitsumori's (there are different opinions.) generation.

sen.j: 室町時代には京都扶持衆として、自らを「会津守護」と称していた。
sen.e: In the Muromachi period, the descendant of the family who was Kyoto fuchishu presented himself as "Shugo of Aizu Province".
During the Muromachi period, a descendant of the family who presented himself as "Shugo of Aizu Province" while being Kyoto fuchishu.

During the Muromachi period, the Aizu Ashina clan had a direct lord-vassal relationship with the Muromachi shogunate and the members of the clan called themselves Governors of Aizu (Aizu Shugo in Japanese).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 戦国時代 (日本)に英主・蘆名盛氏が現われ最盛期を迎えた。
sen.e: In the Warring States period (Japan), the wise lord Moriuji ASHINA was descended and the family was at the height of prosperity.
During the Warring States period (Japan), the wise lord Moriuji ASHINA brought the family to the height of its prosperity.
During the Warring States period (Japan), the wise lord Moriuji ASHINA brought the family to the height of its prosperity.

sen.j: これにより、奥州で伊達氏と並び称される奥州を代表する有力大名にまでのし上がったのである。
sen.e: Then, the family rose to the influential feudal lord representing Oshu (Northern Honshu, the region encompassing Mutsu and Dewa provinces) who was equally admired as the Date clan in the area.

Then, the family rose to a status rivaling that of an influential feudal lord representing Oshu (Northern Honshu, the region encompassing Mutsu and Dewa provinces) who was almost as powerful as the Date clan.

Then, the family rose to a status rivaling that of an influential feudal lord representing Oshu (Northern Honshu, the region encompassing Mutsu and Dewa provinces) who was almost as powerful as the Date clan.

sen.j: しかし、蘆名氏は一族猪苗代氏をはじめとする家臣の統制に苦慮した。
sen.e: On the other hand, the Ashina clan had a hard time controlling its retainers including the Inawashiro clan, a branch of the Ashina clan; and besides, in the later years of Moriuji, they had a problem of settling the succession.

On the other hand, the Ashina clan had a hard time controlling its retainers including the Inawashiro clan, a branch of the Ashina clan. Additionally, during Moriuji's reign, they faced issues concerning sucession.
On the other hand, the Ashina clan had a hard time controlling its retainers including the Inawashiro clan, a branch of the Ashina clan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: さらに盛氏の晩年には後継者問題も発生した。
sen.e: Additionally, during Moriuji's reign, they faced issues concerning succession.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処スペル

sen.j: そのため1580年、盛氏の死とともに蘆名氏は次第に衰え始める。
sen.e: For those reasons, the Ashina clan started to decline when Moriuji died.
For these reasons, the Ashina clan began their decline after Moriuji passed away.
For these reasons, the Ashina clan began their decline after Moriuji passed away in 1580.

sen.j: 盛氏の死後、二階堂氏からの人質の二階堂盛義の子が婿養子として後を継いだ。
sen.e: After the death of Moriuji, the son of Moriyoshi NIKAIDO, a hostage from the NIKAIDO family, succeeded Moriuji as a Moriuji's adopted son-in-law.
After the death of Moriuji, the son of Moriyoshi NIKAIDO, a hostage from the NIKAIDO family, succeeded Moriuji as Moriuji's adopted son-in-law.
After the death of Moriuji, the son of Moriyoshi NIKAIDO, a hostage from the NIKAIDO clan, succeeded Moriuji as Moriuji's adopted son-in-law.

sen.j: 蘆名盛隆である。
sen.e: He was Moritaka ASHINA.
He was Moritaka ASHINA.
He was Moritaka ASHINA.

sen.j: 周辺諸氏と友好を保ち伊達氏に対抗したり、織田信長に使者を送るなど積極的な政策を打ち出す。
sen.e: Moritaka hammered out positive policies including trying to cope with the Date clan by maintaining friendly relations with adjacent clans and sending an envoy to Nobunaga ODA, but he was still hard to control the retainers of the Ashina clan.

Moritaka hammered out positive policies including trying to cope with the Date clan by maintaining friendly relations with adjacent clans and sending an envoy to Nobunaga ODA. However, he still faced difficulties in controlling Ashina clan's retainers.
Moritaka hammered out positive policies including trying to cope with the Date clan by maintaining friendly relations with adjacent clans and sending an envoy to Nobunaga ODA.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: しかし、家中の統制には苦慮している。
sen.e: However, he still faced difficulties in controlling Ashina clan's retainers.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: 1584年に近従の大庭三左衛門に暗殺され、その後を継いだ盛隆の遺児亀若丸（蘆名亀王丸）も1586年に3歳で夭逝。
sen.e: In 1584, Moritaka was assassinated by his attendant Sanzaemon OBA, and in 1586, Kamewakamaru (Kameomaru ASHINA), Moritaka's orphaned son who succeeded Moritaka, died young at the age of three.
In 1584, Moritaka was assassinated by his attendant Sanzaemon OBA, and in 1586, Kamewakamaru (Kameomaru ASHINA), Moritaka's orphaned son who succeeded Moritaka, died at the young age of three.
In 1584, Moritaka was assassinated by his attendant Sanzaemon OBA, and in 1586, Kamewakamaru (Kameomaru ASHINA), Moritaka's orphaned son who succeeded Moritaka, died at the young age of three.

sen.j: そして家臣団が揉めに揉めた末、佐竹義重 (十八代当主)の子・蘆名義広を蘆名家当主に迎えた。
sen.e: After a trouble, the vassals received Yoshihiro ASHINA, a son of Yoshishige SATAKE (the eighteenth head of the clan) as the head of the Ashina clan.
After these problems, the vassals received Yoshihiro ASHINA, a son of Yoshishige SATAKE (the eighteenth head of the clan) as the head of the Ashina clan.
After these problems, the vassals received Yoshihiro ASHINA, a son of Yoshishige SATAKE (the eighteenth head of the clan) as the head of the Ashina clan.

sen.j: 盛氏の死から10年を経ずして3人もの当主が入れ替わったことは、蘆名氏の衰微を象徴するものであった。
sen.e: As symbolizing the decline of the Ashina clan, the head of the clan had changed three times in less than ten years from the death of Moriuji.
The decline of the Ashina clan was symbolized by a change in the leadership of the clan which occurred three times in less than ten years from the death of Moriuji.
The decline of the Ashina clan was symbolized by a change in the leadership of the clan which occurred three times in less than ten years from the death of Moriuji.

sen.j: 1589年、奥州統一を目指す伊達政宗に摺上原の戦いで大敗した蘆名義広は常陸国に逃走し、ここに蘆名氏は没落する。
sen.e: In 1589, Yoshihiro ASHINA was soundly defeated by Masamune DATE, who was ambitious to unify Oshu, in the Suriagehara War and fled to Hitachi Province where the Ashina clan fell into ruin.
In 1589, Yoshihiro ASHINA was soundly defeated by Masamune DATE, who was seeking to unify Oshu, in the Suriagehara War and fled to Hitachi Province where the Ashina clan fell into ruin.
In 1589, Yoshihiro ASHINA was soundly defeated in the Battle of Sekigahara by Masamune DATA, who strived to unify the Oshu region, and fled to Hitachi Province, bringing an end to the Ashina clan.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 実家の佐竹氏に戻った義広は名を「蘆名盛重」と改めて、常陸江戸崎城主となる（江戸崎藩）が、関ヶ原の戦いの際には、旗幟を鮮明にしなかった実兄・佐竹義宣 (右京大夫)と行動を共にしたために改易した。
sen.e: Yoshihiro returned to the family in which he was born, renamed himself "Morishige ASHINA", and became the lord of Edosaki-jo Castle (the Edosaki Domain) in Hitachi Province, but he was ordered Kaieki (forfeit rank of Samurai and properties) because he acted in concert with his elder brother by blood Yoshinobu SATAKE (Ukyo no daibu (Master of the Western Capital Offices)) who did not raise the standard in the Battle of Sekigahara, and Morishige was granted Kakunodate Castle in Dewa and 16 thousand koku as a retainer of the Satake clan; though, after his death, his sons died one after another and the last head of the clan Sentsurumaru Ashina died in an accident at the age of three, which was the end of the line and the Ashina clan ruined both nominally and virtually.

Yoshihiro returned to the family in which he was born, renamed himself "Morishige ASHINA", and became the lord of Edosaki-jo Castle (the Edosaki Domain) in Hitachi Province, but he was ordered Kaieki (forfeit rank of Samurai and properties) because he acted in concert with his elder brother by blood Yoshinobu SATAKE (Ukyo no daibu (Master of the Western Capital Offices)) who did not raise their standard in the Battle of Sekigahara. Morishige was granted Kakunodate Castle in Dewa and 16 thousand koku as a retainer of the Satake clan; though, after his death, his sons died one after another and the last head of the clan Sentsurumaru Ashina died in an accident at the age of three, who was the last of the line, leaving the Ashina clan in ruin.

Yoshihiro returned to his parents' family, renamed himself Morishige ASHINA and became the lord of Edosaki-jo Castle (in the Edosaki Domain), but he was deprived of his territory because he acted in concert with his elder brother, Yoshinobu SATAKE (also known as Ukyo Daibu), without taking a clear stand during the Battle of Sekigahara.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 次いで佐竹家臣として出羽角館城に1万6000石を与えられたものの、盛重の死後、息子が相次いで病死、最後の当主蘆名千鶴丸も3歳で事故死したために家系は断絶して蘆名氏は名実ともに滅亡した。
sen.e: Morishige was granted Kakunodate Castle in Dewa and 16 thousand koku as a retainer of the Satake clan; though, after his death, his sons died one after another and the last head of the clan Sentsurumaru ASHINA died in an accident at the age of three, who was the last of the line, leaving the Ashina clan in ruin.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: なお、蘆名家の一門であった針生氏は蘆名家滅亡後に伊達氏に仕え、この系統は延宝4年（1676年）に仙台藩主・伊達綱村の命により蘆名に改姓した。
sen.e: Incidentally, after the extinction of the Ashina clan, the Hariu family which was a branch of the Ashina family served the Date clan, and in 1676, had their family name changed under orders of Tsunamura DATE, the lord of Sendai Domain.

Incidentally, after the extinction of the Ashina clan, the Hariu family which was a branch of the Ashina family served the Date clan, and in 1676, had their family name changed under orders of Tsunamura DATE, the lord of Sendai Domain.

Incidentally, after the extinction of the Ashina clan, the Hariu family which was a branch of the Ashina family served the Date clan, and in 1676, had their family name changed to Ashina under orders of Tsunamura DATE, the lord of Sendai Domain.
